review_title: If you need a flexible job.
job_title: Patient Care Assistant (PCA) in Lancaster, PA
pros: Flexible shifts, no license needed to work as a “CNA”, good health insurance plans, very clean building
cons: Low pay, high patient to staff ratios, entire hospital is constantly understaffed, false promises made, biweekly pay, difficult to navigate tuition reimbursement, hospital was short handed on many basic things patients need.

pros: Pay is not competitive, but overtime and incentives / bonuses plentiful Teamwork exists on units Managers in certain areas appreciate staff and are present, helpful, available and VISIBLE
cons: Inconsistent Management Support--of the 3 units, each feels like you're working in an entirely different organization Low Base Pay No follow through with issues--some managers try, some don't. Directors and the suits sure don't care about staff EMR is a nightmare, promotes errors --missed orders/documentation misses Your voice is only heard if you're well liked Leadership and staff are very clicky--the ones who don't fit in, will be pushed out

job_title: Physician Assistant in Camp Hill, PA
pros: Good benefits, PTO, 401K matching after 3 years
cons: Can have areas with quick turnover esp within nursing

pros: Teams are friendly enough, always overtime available, opportunities to expand your skills
cons: department drama, management has favorites for sure, preferential treatment for scheduling and assignments, pay increases are far and few between-often not getting raises for cost of living like other departments do.

pros: Doctors and Providers in ED are great
cons: Low pay ; no incentive for getting triage or trauma trained . No differential for triage or trauma .

review_title: No regard for anyone outside nursing
job_title: Pharmacy Technician in Camp Hill, PA
pros: Lead tech does her best to keep her staff happy but even she is being worn down and not able to help with any employee issue.
cons: Underpaid. Overworked. High turnover. Worthless management. Pharmacy director was working from home and lying about it, saying she was traveling between the two facilities daily. Supervisory staff will NOT step in when shifts need covered, techs are expected to pick up 100% of them, and if not, low man on the totem pole is assigned the shift. Company has no regard for anyone outside nursing. They stopped paying departments outside nursing for overtime so they could AFFORD to pay the nurses when they can’t do ANYTHING themselves. The whole place is crumbling, spare yourself the headache and look for employment elsewhere. If you’re not willing to be a yes man, you’ll get bullied out. If you’re a hard worker, they’ll coddle the lazy one. Do you like spending time with your family? Sucks. You’ll never go to another family event again. Want to promote? You won’t because you were never drinking buddies with the director. They make sure they have extra time off for the holidays yet when someone calls off they don’t step in as any other management team would be expected to. Worst. Job. I’ve. Ever. Had.

pros: The management team for the department has been phenomenal. My coworkers on my shift are kind and helpful.
cons: Since it's a newer facility, there are some bumps and hiccups, but overall I have loved working here.

review_title: Strong nurse's union, however satisfaction depends highly on leadership in charge/unit
pros: -Great place for new nurse's with the graduate nurse residency program. I went through it and felt supported when I was new -Benefits are decent - on par with other hospitals in the area. -Strong nurse's union who will go to bat for you and your concerns -Opportunities for advancing your career and growing are generally plentiful -Lots of educational opportunities for nurses.
cons: -Pay: not bad but not great either. You can definitely make more at other hospitals -Depending on unit - unit culture/leadership.

review_title: Nice place to work but very less salary & low growth opportunity
pros: Great environment to work. Offers flexibility such as work from home. Nice retirement package and generous PTO. 75% tuition discount is worth it if you are full time. Other benefits are average. Good for someone who wants to gain experience in healthcare as entry-level.
cons: Salary in the low end, does not provide upward flexibility or much growth opportunity. Everything needs to be approved by HR which takes forever. High turnover rate due to low salary. I don't think yearly bonus are paid every year. Also, annual raise 3-4% not good to keep up with inflation.

cons: Toxic culture. Silos at every corner. High turnover, even senior leadership is brand new. Technology is so far behind. There is no culture of safety. The HR system paints a perfect picture - if you want to move out of your current role and apply for a different position, this information is visible to your current manager/supervisor. Who likes those choices?

New U President who appears hands-off.

pros: There are so many good people here.

review_title: Warm bodies to fill positions need only apply!
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Hershey, PA
pros: Coworkers and interacting with patients.
cons: Leadership. The culture. The technology that fails at almost every turn because they wanted to save money/cut corners. They claim to be all about RITE values but where is the respect for your own employees? Where is the excellence in who and how you hire people? You want to line the higher ups pockets with as much money as possible yet ignore the full scope of the players in your hospital system. The nurses are great and needed of course, but where are the retention bonuses for the people who make you your money? Who identify patients, who code every single thing they go through while in our hospitals and clinics, who cleans up after everyone? You should be ashamed of how you treat your non medical employees.

job_title: Director of Operations in Hershey, PA
pros: Compensation and benefits are attractive. Staff and co-workers are supportive
cons: For such a big-name Health Care system, they are stuck in the dark ages. It is embarrassing the resources you have to fight for. Senior leadership appears supportive in public but is rude and dismissive behind closed doors. People are afraid to speak up for fear of retaliation, therefore things will never change. There is no work-life balance, no one cares if you are working seven days a week, 24 hours a day. Leadership only cares about what you produce but care nothing about you as a person.

pros: Great co-workers who function well as a team.
cons: Short staffing and unrealistic excessive call resulting in terrible work-life balance.

review_title: Eh it’s a good beginner job
job_title: Medical Office Associate in Hershey, PA
pros:
Good benefits
Stable job
Company has good reputation
cons:
Management is lacking
Board does not seem to care about high turn over of entry level positions 
Pay isn’t comparable for type of work provided 
Abuse from physicians is rampant
No room for growth

pros:
Co-workers are great within HR

Direct management is good and does not micromanage

Working remotely - although senior HR leadership constantly tries to tell us that we should come into the office. The reality is, zero HR employees actually want to go back to that environment. Remote work is here to stay.
cons:
HR Leadership is too far removed to see burnout. It is truly a horrible environment right now.

Pay is extremely low - cant compete to land new talent. Our team is past running on fumes and I cant work here much longer.

The health system is growing too fast - each recruiter has 100+ requisitions

Mass exodus of HR employees are leaving

ZERO ACCOUNTABILITY - Good employees get ALL of the work while other employees are never held accountable for doing the bare minimum (or less).

CHRO pumps his fist, tells you he appreciates you, but never seems genuine. He also makes inappropriate remarks constantly - just an extremely poor leader. Waits until things are terrible before taking any action - very "reactive" leader.

Benefits cost a lot - you pay for premium healthcare but you can literally NEVER get an appointment at any specialty clinic without waiting 6+ months. What is the point of having healthcare if you cant get an appointment?

Hiring Managers are toxic - nearly all of them lead by fear and again, there is zero accountability for the way they speak/yell/curse at Human Resources employees.

Bad HR System - the company decided to go with "Infor" and their "Reimagined" product suite. We spent the last 7 years with Infor and their terrible HR system. So what does the CHRO decide? LETS GO WITH THEM AGAIN! It was the single worst implementation in Penn State Health history and continues to be a major pain point. On top of not being able to do our jobs in HR due to the extremely high work loads, we also cant do our jobs because the system is terrible. Then, multiple subject matter experts on the system left the company so now we are in an even worse spot. Thanks leadership for this self-inflicted wound!

pros: Preceptors were extremely helpful and devoted, flexible schedule, supportive team

pros: Not much positive to say about St. Joseph's OBGYN department
cons: The most toxic and bullying work environment I've ever worked in. No leadership or management holding anyone accountable. The bullying and toxicity continues because nothing is done to correct it. Run far away from this place.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Hershey, PA

cons: The admins care most when something is on the line but don’t always care when they should just out of being a caring employer.

job_title: Advanced Practice Provider (PA/NP) in Hershey, PA
pros: Most of the APPS with whom I worked were great coworkers, intelligent, and caring. Decent benefits as well. Many of the attending physicians were easy to work with, knowledgeable, and treated their APP colleagues well.
cons: The Administration was sub-par. Very little true involvement in the working arena; far-removed from the "meat and potatoes" of what made the department run. As a teaching hospital, the residents were encouraged to be lazy, and the APPs were spread thin throughout the department, often carrying patient loads of 3-4x that of the more senior residents. Very little advocacy for the APP group as a whole, primarily with schedules, and overnight support.

review_title: Happy to be a part of the team that helps others during their worst days.
pros:
-Work-life balance: One of the biggest pros is work-life balance with six-days on (three 12-hour day shifts, followed by three 12-hour night shifts), then six-days off. Great to be able to plan out vacations throughout the year. 
-Medical crews are very competent and a pleasure to work with.
-401K match up to 5%.
cons: -NO extra pay for any time worked past 12 hours: Most other helicopter air ambulance agencies pay pilots time and a half for overtime hours worked over a 12-hour shift. There is no extra pay past 12 hours and pilots routinely fly up to 14-hour shifts.

job_title: Medical Call Center Scheduler(Csp Scheduler) in Camp Hill, PA

cons: The community of the company is awful quite frankly, and the company itself seems to be more focused on financial profit. They treat their physicians and other employees that were acquired in any of their mergers awfully. In the administrative roles there is absolutely no room for growth, only lateral career shifts. Management is unresponsive.

job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist in Hershey, PA
pros: Good PTO they have a great health plan and you get a lot of experience with the different cases that come in especially with the Amish and Mennonite community and the rare diseases that exist with them. PIMCU is a very special experience you can not get at most hospitals their pediatric rehab team does a fantastic job educating parents so that children can go home earlier. Great town to have a hospital in you feel very safe walking to and from your car and you can grab meals for takeout or even go out pre covid to get great food!
cons: There seems to be a short coming amongst staff as far as their cultural awareness. There is culture vision on the actual info rt and it does a great job outlining every culture and religion and how they deal with medical care so it’s not so much the institution failing the staff it’s just very typical central PA ignorance and the stubbornness to remain ignorant and prejudice to cultures they don’t agree with. The wages here are some of the lowest in the state for respiratory and your opinions on care are not valued, they do not use research based medicine to treat the children in the PICU With tidal volumes of 10-12 and low PEEP with ordered q4 open bag lava he suctioning even in their heart unit they will ask you to give albuterol to a patient with CHF.

review_title: Resource poor and behind the times
pros: There are talented individuals here - both clinicians and researchers. cons: The leadership is disconnected with the clinical needs of physicians. Basic things like scheduling, patient reminders for appointments, support staff, etc. are woefully behind the times.

job_title: Patient Account Associate in Hershey, PA
pros: The pros and cons are very dependant on who your supervisor is. Luckily I had a wonderful supervisor who genuinely cared about her staff and was very flexible and understanding with hours and time off. PTO is pretty good and the tuition assistance they provide is wonderful.
cons: Yearly raises are tiny and do not often make up for each year's rising insurance premiums which after getting a tiny raise and then being socked with a yearly insurance premium increase, you can easily be left with a smaller paycheck than the year prior. this has happened to me for the last 2 years. Also. it used to feel like a family and management maintained a very nice balance between making sure the revenue was coming in as well as making sure staff felt appreciated. New HR policies and various new directors have changed the atmosphere and many employees are starting to feel like just a number.

review_title: The floor you're on makes all the difference...
job_title: Nurse Extern and Student in Hershey, PA
pros:
-large academic medical center (you learn a lot!)
-nice location (safe)
cons:
-if you are a person of color you will not get hired on more "prestigious" floors. The children's hospital nurses are all rich white sorority girls, and unless you fit this criteria you will not be hired...no diversity at all no matter what they tell you through their slogans (besides the doctors and med students which the managers cannot control). This also depends on the floor you're on. I've seen floors fully staffed with blacks, asians, whites (everyone basically and usually med-surg floors) and then you go to the children's hospital and it's the opposite. Sad that this is a reality for people of color here...

-turnover!! when I was a nurse extern my preceptor was the nurse there the longest (she was a new nurse with 2 years of experience) and even she ended up leaving shortly...

-the pay is absolute garbage. I took my first RN position somewhere else bc i was getting paid 5 dollars more there than what i would have if i stayed in hershey...

review_title: I was an RN here for almost 2 years in the Neuroscience ICU.
pros: Great 401K and benefits. Education assistance. PTO payout. Some opportunities to learn and advance in your career. Looks good on a resume, that’s about it.
cons: Bullying from RNs that had been there longer & were jaded. Favoritism from management & leadership with certain RNs - would give unfair assignments & the “sick” patients to the favorites. Continual problem with staffing and not enough help, aids are lazy and RNs do literally everything. On the IMC side, you’d have 3 total care patients and most other RNs are unwilling to help reposition, majority of the time I felt like I was neglecting my patients if one was more complicated than another. Neurosurgery residents are disrespectful to say the ABSOLUTE LEAST - ignore text pages & calls when their patients are on the IMC side of the unit. When there was a charge nurse on the IMC side, they would sit the entire day & text, rather than help. Management was told countless times, but nothing ever changed. The turnover rate is extremely high as the unit is hard to work on - RNs are not very welcoming or willing to help you learn. Management and Educator are straight up rude when critiquing individuals when they’re on orientation, to the point that they make you cry.

pros: Everyone is excited to work for Penn State. The overall morale of the employees as a whole is wonderful and I truly feel motivated that I get to work for PSU in this capacity. The benefits are wonderful: health insurance is great, dental and eye coverage is great, PTO is amazing, and other benefits are lovely. For the most part, most employees are pleasant and interested in their work and at the heart of their job have patient care and satisfaction in mind.
cons:
Opportunity to advance is limited because of the inside politics - it's a game of who-knows-who. This is detrimental to those who enter on a base level because of experience but then are looking to advance because of education or interest in another department. There should be a bigger drive to promote from within based on merit and education, not just connections and politics.

Pay, based on your position, isn't always equal to your position. There are several positions that are underpaid but overworked. This is also dependent on department.

review_title: Great place to work, very proud of my the work done here, kind and caring people
pros: Very supportive, kind and caring individuals and staff.  Big egos simply do not exist or have a place here.  Throwing your weight around and being overly bossy is looked down upon.  The hospital solely and truly exists for achieving quality patient care and delivering the best possible outcome with not only the patient's best interest in mind, but the family as well.  An environment that truly fosters individual excellence, innovation, and research.
cons: Management recognizes potential and effort and rewards success with praise, but needs to work better with HR on providing these opportunities so that talented individuals are retained in the institution.  Needs to play catch-up with some of the bigger medical centers (penn, upmc, hopkins, etc.) but is slowly getting there in terms of the new health care reform, but the culture of Central PA hampers this.

job_title: Catering to You Associate in Hershey, PA
pros: I enjoy being around the patients and helping them. There is always overtime available if you are interested. Co workers are friendly and fun to work with.
cons: Only paid $10.00 an hour. Managers are negative towards employees. Typically leave my house in the morning at 6, clock in by 630am and don't leave until 7-730 PM. Can't get all the work that needs to be done in a day completed in the 12 hour shifts. Managers are constantly adding more responsibilities, yet not properly compensating employees. Responsible for patients lives, but treated insignificantly by doctors, nurses, etc.. Not paid for the responsibility and care that needs to be taken to ensure patient safety. Work for a union that decreased the original employee hourly wage, yet we pay them dues for fighting for our rights. Management more concerned about times, and less worried about being precise. Don't feel valued or appreciated for hard work that job entails.

review_title: Small town, big hospital, but little room for advancement
pros: Overall there is a great sharing of information and knowledge in the interest of the patient at HMC. It is a very nice hospital to work at- new, clean and safe. Parking is free and easy.
cons: There is not much room for advancement. People do not leave this place because it is an easy place to work.  Small town, big hospital, cheap place to live. However, it leaves little room for advancement for up and comers.  Pay is mediocre and it is one of the few hospitals that differentiates pay between MLTs and MTs. Hershey is trying very hard to compete with CHOP and Hopkins, but stretching their workers thin.

pros: Job security, benefits and general salary is good. The location is rural and safe and close to many interesting cities and outdoor activities. The relationship to Penn State is a real plus and opens up a lot of personal opportunities. Staff really cares for the patients and their families. It's authentic.
cons: Very political. Getting things through key decision makers can be challenging. Items are often slowed in committees and the overall feel is very institutional. Many legacy employees struggle to let go of things of the past and this creates an uninviting culture from colleagues.

pros:
401K match dollar for dollar at 5%
Health Insurance
My schedule is slightly more flexible than other employees' here.
cons:
Horrible management. Everything is micromanaged. You are treated like a child with horrible parent, being scolded for every little thing and never praised for anything.
The company almost never hires from within for higher administrative positions, resulting in new and unknown people coming in trying to change things every few months.
The suggestions of the people who are actually on the ground floors working are completely ignored most of the time.
Employees constantly bash each other behind everyone's back like middle-schoolers because they hate their jobs and don't want to be here (like middle-schoolers).
Little chance for advancement (contrary to what they tell you).

review_title: Good People, Good Medicine, Good Residency
pros: Tertiary referal center keeps the hosptial busy, seem to have an eye on the future, and making decisions and planning for the future.
cons: In the unfortunate ever increasing demand for capitol to continue to operate, decisions are a little to bottom line oriented.  A new childrens hospital is being constructed, that will not increase the capacity of the hospital for children at its completion.  It will really only serve to increase OR space, and is an expensive marking ploy.

review_title: Work at PSU, the medical school at Hershey
pros: If you like small town work environment, then Hershey is a place to go and not that far away from big cities.  And no or low traffic to work
cons: You need to have a good boss who knows and cares what you are doing.  Make sure you have the financial support you need for the term before come.  If not, it is hard to find a job without moving in such small town.

review_title: HVICCU - and charge nurse are great examples of bullying, poor leadership and poor communication skills.
pros: Great opportunities to care for high acuity patients and learn a great deal. Ok benefits, there are a few good preceptors and if you are lucky enough to get one you’ll do great!
cons: Terrible leadership, inexperienced new clinical educator and complete lack of mentor ship. A whole unit of unexperienced leaders and the ones who have experience are bitter and eat their young. Perfect examples of what is wrong with nursing.

pros: They never cut hours and we have gotten a raise annually in addition to an annual bonus every year since I started there (6 yrs ago).  Plus a 75% tuition bonus for a Penn State education!
cons: It's hard to promote within the company since there is so much competition nationally for top positions

pros: Generally a good place to work with A lower stress environment, pleasant people and for the most part atmosphere.  Still room for improvement though.
cons: New management to oversee Access Center (call center) has zero experience in field thus limiting personal development.  They are also listening to wrong people on the front lines. Bad workers filtering their way through the system. Access Center is busting at the seems for space and technology and we are on bottom of list as we do not capture headlines.

pros:
Pay
Cost of benefits 
Physical work conditions 
Tuition discount at PSU
Extra Personal Time given 
Smell of chocolate in the air
cons:
Management can not retire soon enough
Cliquish, unprofessional, gossipy, bullies, favoritism, preferential treatment given to some 
Does not listen to suggestions for improvement 
Walks around aimlessly looking to socialize 
Limited job advancement

review_title: Too much drama allowed at front line levels and senior leadership enables collusion among negative employees.
pros: Tuition reimbursement, paid time off
cons: Negative employees allowed to collude against good leaders.  Poor communication across units.  Too many Directors and VP's. Senior leadership not engaged and won't confront poor performers.  Medical benefits aren't as good as they should be.  Very little is covered until you hit your deductible.

review_title: Amazing Place! Pediatric Acute Care Unit
pros:
Supportive co-workers and management
Many resources to help you care for patients
Awesome kiddos & families to care for 
So many opportunities to learn!
cons:
There is a nursing union which means a lot of decisions are based on seniority only. CNAs are also in a union, which presents some issues. 

The union does have benefits in terms of protecting patient ratio, PTO,  scheduling, and benefits.

pros: The experience, nice looking facility and good benefits
cons: Poor management and coworker interactions.

pros: The benefits at PSHMC are good. Fellow employees are nice.
cons: At times too many projects being worked on or started at the same time. Due to the size of the campus one may have a distance to travel from assigned parking lot to work area.  However there are complimentary shuttle buses that can be used so one does not have to walk.

review_title: Interesting research, but poor pay and disorganized labs
job_title: Research Technician I in Hershey, PA
pros: The research was very interesting, and some labs did some really cool stuff. The benefits were also extensive and supportive (especially healthcare).
cons: Every lab I worked in was terribly disorganized, and the PI's were micromanaging and discouraged Research Technicians from pursuing their passions, and discouraged me from academic research in general.

pros: tuiton assistance and making contacts. Get certifications and move on
cons: No career opportunities unless your a crony with security mgmt. They dnt promote based on qualifications. Limited diversity for leadership positions. Cronyism is real in tht dept. To many false alarms n door unlocks. Not security work that you would think you should perform. Officers r gossippers like babys. Low moral low pay

job_title: Catering to You Associate in Hershey, PA
pros: I love my schedule. It's rotating every other weekend.  Supervisors and managers are awesome.  Benefits are great.  Pto is great as well.  Pay is awesome. Raises.
cons: Employees with bad attitudes.  I'm in food services. And no free food.  But we throw so much away.  Hours are long. 10 to 12 hour day depending on ur position.

job_title: Operating Room Nurse in Harrisburg, PA
pros: Fast-paced environment. Was able to help treat patients in some really bad circumstances. Refine my skills in regards to working well under pressure. Performed a lot of the sales functions, as the reps were not always present for cases. Was active in both the scrub and circulation roles. Refined my prioritization and critical thinking skills. Participated in Practice and Education Councils.
cons: Promoting within the hospital was not done; therefore, hard, dedicated work was not rewarded.

pros: Ability to grow within the organization through leadership and development offerings. Ability to experiment with Innovative ideas. Great opportunities exist
cons: Work life family balance is challenging - some leaders need to be more supportive of life balance. Employee engagement and burnout needs to be a priority in the organization.

pros: Benefits, college assistance for employee (spouses and kids), short-term and long-term disability insurance, ability to go to school while you work, room to advance, some training available.
cons: non-empathetic management when it comes to illness and tardiness (weather related or otherwise), culture caters to hierarchy, parking.

review_title: Good place with plenty of job security
pros: The benefits and pay are good. My supervisor is knowledgeable and has done this job. Job diversity and job security are also pluses.
cons: There is a lot of work currently with quite a bit in the pipeline. Working on a hospital setting can be difficult.

pros:
1. You only work 3 12 hour shifts a week.
2. Working every third weekend instead of every other.
3. Health insurance starts the same day as you.
4.Tuition reimbursement for yourself and your family.
cons:
1.Some units are very outdated (changes are coming).
2.Equipment not always working (dynamap and/or portable pulse ox).
3.Admitting people for no reason (narc seekers).
4.Discharging people too soon.
